citation.article-title: A new facultatively nitrite oxidizing bacterium, Nitrobacter vulgaris sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Nitrobacter vulgaris sp. nov.
Pleomorphic mostly pear-shaped cells are 0.5-0.8 μm in diameter and 1.2- 2.0 μm in length.
They are motile by one polar to subpolar flagellum.
Intracytoplasmic membranes are forming caps of flattened vesicles.
Cells produce extracellular polymeres at all growth conditions, causing the formation of a biofilm.
Facultative lithoautotrophs that oxidize nitrite to nitrate under aerobic conditions and reduce nitrate to nitrite, ammonia, nitric and nitrous oxide under anaerobic conditions.
Lithoautotrophic growth often is slower than chemoorganotrophic growth.
Most of the strains show diphasic growth.
When growing mixotrophically first nitrite and then the organic matter is oxidized.
Optimum lithoautotrophic growth was observed between 23 and 28°C and pH values between 7.5 and 8.0.
The mol% G+C of DNA is 59.4±0.5.
Strains were isolated from soils, groundwater, fresh and brakish water environments, sewage disposal plants, concrete and natural sandstone of buildings and a termite heap.
Type strain: Nitrobacter vulgaris "Z" - culture collection of the Institut für Allgemeine Botanik der Universität Hamburg, Mikrobiologische Abteilung, FRG.
